arguments.claim: High Court can suo motu act against subordinate court orders in proper cases, but not justified here

anchor.surface_text: We, however, make it clear that we have numberdoubt that in proper cases the High Court can take action suo moto against the orders passed by the subordinate companyrts-without being moved by any party.

holdings.text: The Division Bench was not justified in interfering with the orders dated March 20, and June 8, 1967 passed by the Chief Presidency Magistrate, in the circumstances of this case.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly hold that the Division Bench was number justified in interfering with the orders dated March 20, and June 8, 1967 passed by the Chief Presidency Magistrate, in the circumstances of this case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Division Bench ignored concession on misconceived process under ss.337/338 IPC, Single Judge finding of no offence disclosed, valid discharge under s.253(2) CrPC given good reasons including complainant conduct and Sen Commission inquiry.

holdings.text: The Division Bench committed fundamental error by proceeding on basis that Single Judge did not hold prosecution under ss.337 and 338 IPC not made out, ignoring concession and categorical finding.

anchor.surface_text: The fundamental error companymitted by the Division Bench is that it has proceeded on the basis that the learned Single Judge on the former occasion in Criminal Revision No. 19 of 1967 has number held that the prosecution under ss. 337 and 338 is number made out.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Counsel for complainant conceded process misconceived; Single Judge discussed ingredients and held statements do not constitute essential elements for offences under ss.337/338 IPC.

holdings.text: Statements in complaint do not constitute essential elements of offences under ss.337 and 338 IPC; no offence disclosed thereunder.

anchor.surface_text: Again even apart from the companycession, the learned Single Judge after discussing the essential ingredients of an offence under ss. 337 and 338 P.C. has categorically held in his order that the statements made in the companyplaint petition do number go to make ,up the essential ingredients for an offence under ss. 337 and 338.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Upholding Single Judge's independent consideration of averments post-concession; Magistrate bound by this direction limiting to s.336 IPC inquiry.

holdings.text: Under s.253(2) CrPC, Magistrate has jurisdiction to discharge accused at any previous stage if charge groundless, for reasons recorded; sub-s(1) no bar.

anchor.surface_text: Even under such circumstances, the Magistrate has got ample jurisdiction to discharge the accused under s. 253 2  P.C. Section 253 deals with the discharge of accused. Subsection  1  deals with the discharge... Sub-section  2  of s. 253 is to the following effect 253 2  Nothing in this section shall be deemed to prevent a Magistrate from discharging the accused at any previous stage of the case if, for reasons to be recorded by such Magistrate, he companysiders the charge to be groundless.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of s.253(2); Magistrate gave good reasons; applies even in warrant procedure cases under ss.337/338.

holdings.text: Chief Presidency Magistrate discharged accused under s.253(2) CrPC giving good reasons, including complainant's conduct and ongoing Sen Commission inquiry; discharge valid and justified.

anchor.surface_text: It is under sub-section  2  of s. 253 that the Magistrate has discharged the accused. He has given good reasons in the order for discharging the accused. Assuming that the Division Bench is right in holding that the discharge

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reasons recorded as required; no controversy on Sen Commission inquiring identical matter; complainant not serious.

holdings.text: Even if proceedings treated as summons case under s.336 IPC, Magistrate has jurisdiction under s.248 CrPC to permit withdrawal of complaint, leading to acquittal; discharge valid.

anchor.surface_text: Even on the basis that the inquiry has to proceed for an offence under S. 336 I.P.C.-, the position will be that the summons case procedure will have to be followed. Even then, under S. 248 Cr. P.C. the Magistrate has ample jurisdiction to permit the companyplainant to withdraw the companyplaint. In fact under S. 248 Cr. P.C. the Magistrate should acquit the accused,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Post Single Judge order, only s.336 inquiry; summons procedure applies; equivalent to permitting withdrawal.

holdings.text: High Court can take suo motu action against subordinate court orders in proper cases.

anchor.surface_text: We, however, make it clear that we have numberdoubt that in proper cases the High Court can take action suo moto against the orders passed by the subordinate companyrts-without being moved by any party.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clarificatory observation despite no justification in this case.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeal is allowed. The judgment and order of the High Court in Criminal Revision No.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; High Court judgment and order in Criminal Revision No. 475 of 1967 set aside

edges.explanation: Argument that allegations do not constitute essential elements supports the concept that complaint lacks elements for IPC 337 offence.
Argument that allegations do not establish offence under ss. 337/338 addresses the issue of whether complaint disclosed essential elements under those sections.
No justification argument supports holding of not justified interference
Argument of no justification addresses the central issue
Argument on failure to appreciate Single Judge directions supports_arg similar argument on ignoring specific concession.
